Dialogue: You admit that? Then tell me, how did that selection happen?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: There were six guards, so we decided we'd choose ten people each. That's how we did it - every month. We'd all choose ten.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Are you saying your fellow defendants took part in the process?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: We all did.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Even though they've denied it? But you admit it. You're saying you took part in the process.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Did you not realise you were sending these women to their deaths?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Yes but there were new arrivals, new women were arriving all the time, so of course we had to move some of the old ones on.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I'm not sure you understand...

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: We couldn't keep everyone. There wasn't room.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: No, but what I'm saying : let me rephrase : to make room, you were picking women out and saying `You you and you have to be sent back to be killed.'

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Well, what would you have done?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: So should I never have signed up at Siemens?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Ms. Mather, they're ready for you now.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: In your book you describe the process of selection...

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Yes. You were made to work and then, when you were no longer any use to them, then they sent you back to Auschwitz to be killed.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: Are there people here today who made that selection?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: prosecutor
Dialogue: I need you to identify them. Can you please point them out?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Her. And her. And her. And her. And her. And her.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Each of the guards would choose a certain number of women. Hanna Schmitz chose differently.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: In what way differently?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: She had favourites. Girls, mostly young. We all remarked on it, she gave them food and places to sleep. In the evening, she asked them to join her. We all thought - well, you can imagine what we thought.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Then we found out - she was making these women read aloud to her. They were reading to her. At first we thought this guard, this guard is more sensitive, she's more human, she's kinder. Often she chose the weak, the sick, she picked them out, she seemed to be protecting them almost. But then she dispatched them. Is that kinder?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Please tell us about the night in the church.

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We'd arrived in a village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest's house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: Nobody.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Even though you were all burning to death?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: How many people were killed?

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: Everyone was killed.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: How did you survive?

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn't stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can't defend what I did. It's impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn't burn.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Thank you. I want to thank you for coming to this country today to testify.

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: I don't know. I don't know what we're doing any more.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: Don't you?

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: You keep telling us to think like lawyers, but there's something disgusting about this.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: This didn't happen to the Germans. It happened to the Jews.

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: What are we trying to do?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: We're trying to understand.

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: Six women locked    three hundred Jews in a church, and    let them burn. What is there to    understand? Tell me, I'm asking :    what is there to understand?

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: I started out believing in this trial, I thought it was great, now I think it's just a diversion.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: Yes? Diversion from what?

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say `They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones'. Brilliant!

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: People go on about how much did everyone know? `Who knew?' `What did they know?' That isn't the question. The question is `How could you let it happen?' And - better - `Why didn't you kill yourself when you found out?'

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: Thousands! That's how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew.

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: Look at that woman...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Which woman?

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: The woman you're always staring at. I'm sorry but you are.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I don't know which woman you mean.

Speaker: dieter
Dialogue: You know what I'd do? Put the gun in my hand, I'd shoot her myself.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Why did you not unlock the doors?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Why did you not unlock the doors?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I've asked all of you and I'm getting no answer. Two of the victims are in this court. They deserve an answer.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Here, this is the SS report. You all have copies.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: This is the report which was written, approved and signed by all of you immediately after the event. In the written report, you all claim you didn't even know about the fire until after it happened. But that isn't true, is it?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Well? It isn't true.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: I don't know what you're asking.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: The first thing I'm asking is, why didn't you unlock the doors?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Obviously. For the obvious reason. We couldn't.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Why? Why couldn't you?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: We were guards. Our job was to guard the prisoners. We couldn't just let them escape.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I see. And if they escaped, then you'd be blamed, you'd be charged, you might even be executed?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Well then?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: If we opened the doors, then there would have been chaos. How could we have restored order?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: So you did know what was happening? You did know? You made a choice. You let them die rather than risk letting them escape.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: The other defendants have made an allegation against you. Have you heard this allegation?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: They say you were in charge.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: It isn't true. I was just one of the guards.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Did you write the report?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: No. No. We all discussed what to say. We all wrote it together.

Speaker: beckhart
Dialogue: She wrote it! She wrote the report. She was in charge.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Is that true?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: No. And I didn't write the report. Does it matter who did?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: I need to see a sample of your handwriting.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: My handwriting?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes. I need to establish who wrote the report.

Speaker: hanna's counsel
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but I really don't see how that's appropriate. Nearly twenty years have gone by.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Somebody take her this piece of paper.

Speaker: hanna's counsel
Dialogue: Are you really going to compare handwriting of twenty years ago, with handwriting of today?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Give her the paper. Counsel, approach the bench.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: There's no need. I wrote the report.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: You've been skipping seminars.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I have a piece of information. Concerning one of the defendants. Something they're not admitting.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: What information?

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: You don't need me to tell you. It's perfectly clear you have a moral obligation to disclose it to the court.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It happens this information is favourable to the defendant. It can help her case. It may even affect the outcome, certainly the sentencing.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: There's a problem. The defendant herself is determined to keep this information secret.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: A moment, please. Please.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: What are her reasons?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Because she's ashamed.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: Ashamed? Ashamed of what?

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: Have you spoken to her?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: Why of course not?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I can't. I can't do that. I can't talk to her.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: What we feel isn't important. It's utterly unimportant. The only question is what we do.

Speaker: rohl
Dialogue: If people like you don't learn from what happened to people like me, then what the hell is the point of anything?

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: You have a visitor. Michael Berg.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Time's up.

Speaker: marthe
Dialogue: You've taken your time.

Speaker: marthe
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Dialogue: I'm sorry. I need to sleep by myself.

Dialogue: Where are we going?

Dialogue: I said : I'll tell you when we get there. You told me you liked surprises.

Dialogue: I like surprises.

Dialogue: She's grown, hasn't she?

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: I don't know. It's so long since I saw her, Michael, how can I tell?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: My fault. We shouldn't have come unannounced.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Daddy, why's she angry?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I'm afraid I've have some bad news. Julia knows.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Daddy's going to live in his own house.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: You didn't come for your father's funeral, but you come for this?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You know, it's not easy for me to visit this town.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: Were you really so unhappy?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: That's not what I'm saying. It's not what I meant.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: Well then?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You mustn't worry about Gertrud. I'm going to look after her. And anyway, let's face it, she's already a state prosecutor, she earns far more than I do.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: Michael, I'm not worried about Gertrud. I'm worried about you.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Hello Mummy.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Hello beautiful.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Do you mind if I don't ask you in?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I don't mind at all. I've a lot to do, in fact.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I took her to see where I grew up.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: You went to the West? My God, what a trip.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: We went to say hello to granny.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Oh. Daddy took you to see Carla, did he?

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: She was strange.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Come on, let's see what's on TV.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: I bet she was strange.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You could say.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: She always was. Why on earth did you decide to do that?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I don't know. Impulse.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I suppose if I'm honest we went because I wanted to re-establish contact.

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: With your mother? And did you succeed?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Michael you're meant to be an intelligent man. Don't you know, it's very hard to receive contact if you're not willing to give it?

Speaker: gertrud
Dialogue: Say goodbye to Julia.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Goodbye, Daddy.

Dialogue: "Who are you? Where are you from? Your city? Your parents? I'm wonderstruck - you drank my drugs, you're not bewitched..."

Dialogue: The Lady with the Little   Dog, by Anton Chekhov. "The talk   was that a new face had appeared on   the promenade, a lady with a   little dog..."

Dialogue: I want to take out a book.

Dialogue: Which book?

Dialogue: What's your name?

Dialogue: Hanna Schmitz.

Dialogue: The Lady with the Little Dog, a story by Anton Chekhov. The talk was...

Speaker: michael's voice
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I have it here.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You're her only contact. And I'm told you don't visit her.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No. I don't.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: When she gets out, she's going to need a job. She's going to need somewhere to live. You can't imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes. I'm still here.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: I have no-one else to ask. If you don't take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It's kind of you. Thank you for letting me know.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: You're Michael Berg?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: Louisa Brenner. We were expecting you earlier.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: I should warn you: for a long time Hanna held herself together. She was very purposeful. In the last few years she's different. She's let herself go.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: They're in the canteen. They're just finishing lunch.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: You've grown up, kid.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I've got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He'll give you a job. And I've found you somewhere to live. It's a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you'll like it.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there's a public library very close.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You read a lot?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: I prefer being read to.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: That's over now, isn't it?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Did you get married?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I'm not seeing as much of her as I would like. I'd like to see a great deal more of her.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The marriage didn't last.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: You mean, with you?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No. No, I didn't mean with me.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: And now? What do you feel now?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: It doesn't matter what I think. It doesn't matter what I feel. The dead are still dead.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I wasn't sure what you'd learnt.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: I have learnt, kid. I've learnt to read.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I'll pick you up next week, OK?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: That sounds a good plan.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Quietly.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: OK. Quietly.

Speaker: hanna
Dialogue: Take care, kid.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You too.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: See you next week.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: She didn't pack. She never intended to leave.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: She left me a message, a sort of will. I'll read out the bit that concerns you.

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: "There is money in the old tea tin. Give it to Michael Berg. He should send it, alongside the 7,000 marks in the bank, to the daughter who wrote the book. It's for her. She should decide what to do with it. And tell Michael I said hello. Tell him to get on with his life."

Speaker: ms brenner
Dialogue: Do you want to see her?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Ms Mather?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Yes. You're Michael Berg. I was expecting you.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: So you must tell me: what exactly brings you to the United States?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: You're a lawyer?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: I was intrigued by your letter but I can't say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Go on, please.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: She was a friend of yours?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: A kind of friend. It's as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Is that an explanation of her behaviour?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Or an excuse?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She'd always liked being read to.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Why don't you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: When I was young I had an affair with Hanna.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: I'm not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I'm not willing to.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: But what?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she'd had on your life?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: She'd done much worse to other people. I've never told anyone.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren't therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn't go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: To do what?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: As you think fit.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: When I was a little girl, I had a tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: What was in it?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn't stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: There's nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I'm neither willing nor in a position to grant.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Do you know if there's a Jewish organization?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: I'll be surprised if there isn't. There's a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: Why don't you find out? Send them the money.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Shall I do it in Hanna's name?

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: As you think fit.

Speaker: ilana
Dialogue: I'll keep the tin.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I thought you liked surprises.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: I do. I do like surprises.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Hanna Schmitz.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: Who was she?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: That's what I wanted to tell you. That's why we're here.

Speaker: julia
Dialogue: So tell me.
